etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Robert Barnes (c1495–1540), religious reformer. From revive + -or

definitions: A person who or thing which revives, renews, or restores something; a reviver.

etymologies: early 17th century (in an earlier sense). Apparently alteration of reviver (although this is first attested slightly later)

definitions: The process of reviving a suit or action which has been rendered void, especially by the death of one of the parties; an instance of this. Usually in "bill of revivor". Now chiefly US.
